- The last and only full US boycott of an Olympic games was during the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow, to protest the Soviet Union's military presence in Afghanistan. The base likelihood for such an event is thus very low. - The US Olympic Committee has made it clear that it does not support a boycott that would prevent US athletes from competing in Beijing, as “They have been shown to negatively impact athletes while not effectively addressing global issues”. This further supports a low probability of such an announcement. - Such an announcement would become more plausible in the event of a sudden deterioration in US-China relations, possibly triggered by a serious international incident such as a Chinese invasion of Taiwan (which would provide a context to mirror the US's boycott in 1980). The likelihood of such a flare-up happening in this last month before 1 Jan 2022 appears low, particularly given the measured success of the recent Biden-Xi dialogue aimed at defusing the tensions that could lead to such a conflict. As such, the probability assigned to such an announcement is very low but non-zero.

There have been feminist boycotts (British women stayed away from Amsterdam in 1928 when the IOC reneged on its promise to add 10 women’s events to the athletics program), podium protests against racism (Tommie Smith, John Carlos and other U.S. athletes in 1968), so-called recognition boycotts (Taiwan left in 1976 when the IOC refused to call it the “Republic of China”), anti-apartheid boycotts (29 African and Caribbean teams walked out of the Montreal Olympics in 1976 to protest a New Zealand rugby tour of apartheid South Africa) and Cold War boycotts in 1956, 1980, 1984 and 1988. In 1936, an international coalition of socialists, labour unions and churches not only mounted a highly visible boycott campaign against the staging of the Games in Nazi Germany, but tried to hold a counter-Olympics in Barcelona. It was only cancelled when the Spanish general Francisco Franco led an armed attack upon the city on the morning of the opening ceremonies, starting what became the bitter, three-year Spanish Civil War. https://www.wikiwand.com/en/People%27s_Olympiad  House lawmakers push for diplomatic boycott of 2022 Winter Olympics in China - ABC News

I think with Biden as President there is a greater chance of boycotting the Olympics. But I feel that this action would heavily depend on public responses to the Uighur crisis.

Such a measure would be out of character for the Biden administration, which values stability and amicable foreign relations. One thing it does do, however, is allow itself to be swayed to some degree by public sentiment. In 2019, there was an anti-China  wave among progressives and conservatives alike in light of the Hong Kong protests. When public opinion shifted toward Palestine in the US with the 2021 Israel-Palestine conflict, the Biden administration did show a sympathy toward Palestine uncharacteristic of American leadership.  There is momentum building for boycott: scores of human rights organizations have called for it and Biden has not ruled it out. (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2021/04/12/olympics-china-boycott/) The only precedent for this drastic move is the 1980 Moscow Olympics, where the US boycotted at the height of the Cold War.(https://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/carter-announces-olympic-boycott) It was nominally in response to USSR's invasion of Afghanistan, and was instigated by Jimmy Carter, a president who Biden has been compared to.   However, an important factor is the power of the Chinese market—which has been shown to deter such entities as the NBA and Disney from causing any semblance of controversy with the country. (https://www.vox.com/videos/2019/11/11/20959250/china-nba-houston-rockets-hong-kong)  (https://www.cnet.com/features/marvel-is-censoring-films-for-china-and-you-probably-didnt-even-notice/) The fact is that it is dramatically more profitable when American-Chinese relations are calm. This will exert pressure on the White House in the debate over the Olympics.  I think a boycott is unlikely. But if there were some galvanizing event—a Chinese action akin to the USSR invading Afghanistan or further escalation in Hong Kong or with the abuse of Uighurs—public opinion could rise to a fury and push Biden into boycotting. This could create an increasingly rare scenario in which liberals and conservatives are united over a common enemy. Their voice would only need to drown out the impassioned lobbying of the Disneys and NBAs of the world desperate to maintain their global market.

Just redoing my forecast to implement the outside/inside probability method :-) Outside Probability: The US has boycotted the Olympics only once - the Summer Olympics held in Moscow in 1980.  Given there have been 31 Olympic Games, this represents an outside probability of 1/31 = 0.032 (3dp). Inside Probability: The reason the US boycotted the Moscow Olympics in 1980 was because of the Cold War.  Wikipedia describes the state of affair between the USSR and the US at the time: "Carter responded to the Soviet intervention by withdrawing the SALT II treaty from ratification, imposing embargoes on grain and technology shipments to the USSR, and demanding a significant increase in military spending, and further announced that the United States would boycott the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow. He described the Soviet incursion as the most serious threat to the peace since the Second World War" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War).  This all sounds fairly dire.  It's also worth looking at boycotts the US did NOT partake in to understand the things that US are more comfortable with (than other countries who boycotted).  This might gain insight into what the US might be willing to ignore.  Here are two examples:
1976 - Montreal Games boycotted by 22 countries (and not the US) "due to the refusal of the IOC to ban NZ after the NZ national rugby union team had toured SA earlier in 1976" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1976_Summer_Olympics).
1988 - Seoul Olympics boycotted by 7 countries (and not the US) due to lingering tensions stemming from the Cold War (and differences in ideology).
Simply, the US has not previously boycotted based on human rights issues. So I'm reducing the base rate by 1%. P = OutsideP + InsideP
P = 0.032 + -0.01
P = 0.022

That estimate puts me in the "this COULD happen, but I have strong doubts" category. Why the strong doubts? The decision-maker here is the USOPC (its official name), not the US government. Unlike most national Olympic committees, the USOPC gets virtually no direct funding from the US government. (https://www.teamusa.org/about-the-usopc) Most of its funds come from sponsorship and licensing fees and its share of the IOC's television contract revenues and global sponsorship fees. (https://2019impactreport.teamusa.org/USOPC-2019-Consolidated-Financial-Statement.pdf) A USOPC boycott of the 2022 Games would result in a material reduction for these funding sources. I presume that a limited economic and diplomatic "boycott" of the type described in Mitt Romney's NYT op-ed (https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/15/opinion/politics/beijing-olympics-mitt-romney.html) would not resolve the question as "Yes" because those steps would not be announced as a USOPC boycott (the US athletes would still participate in the 2022 Games). The Romney approach offers a good middle ground for the Biden administration to express displeasure with China's treatment of the Uighurs without denying US athletes the right to compete OR asking NBC, the USOPC, and other corporate sponsors of the games to take a major financial hit. Examples of things that could cause me to revise my forecast upward: official announcements by US allies that they are boycotting the Beijing Olympics, Chinese military action against Taiwan or a major escalation in the South China Sea, revelation of a major US corporate IP theft or cyberhacking incident under the auspices of the Chinese government. Otherwise, I expect that the passage of time with no big news flow about a boycott being seriously contemplated will lead me to decrement my forecast down to zero.

1)	When did it happen? Boycotts happened during 6 of the 31 Modern Olympiads since 1896.[1] In total, 31 Summer Olympic Games[2] and 23 Winter Olympic Games[3] were held.
The distinction between Summer and Winter Olympic games is relevant for timing, as both can be boycotted individually, and in regard to political significance, as the Summer Games are perceived to be more important. The USA only boycotted the 1980 Summer Games.[1] -> (1/31)
Only once where Winter Games boycotted; In 1980 by Taiwan. -> (1/23). Crudly assuming equal weight, averaging yields ((1/31)+(1/23))/2, or a probability of 3,8%. 2)	How would it happen? The announcement would be made on behalf of its Board of Directors, having 15 voting members.[4] Each individual vote is influenced by: a)	The USOPC’s interests; Continued existence, revenue, renown.
b)	The advertises interests; Association to the ideas of winning and good.
c)	The Athletes’ interest in competing.
d)	Their personal value hierarchy in weighing these interests; Political views, own career perspectives. 3)	When would it happen? If the USOPC’s boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics became to be seen as having significant meaning to those interest groups, that can affect the USOPC’s decision process and that choose to do so; Athletes, the US-Public, Sponsors, the US-Administration, and their respective stakeholders. a)	Athletes dedicate their waking life to preparation. In 1980, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan was not enough [5], even within the context of the Cold War. So the perception of the preceeding events would have to be substantial for athletes to make the individual or collective choice to boycott the games.
b)	The US-Public does not have direct or indirect authority over the USOPC, but strongly felt general sentiment might have sway under (2a).
c)	Sponsors wish to be associated with the concept of winning in the abstract. If advertisement at the 2022 Winter Games would mean to choose between markets (b/c being seen either as pro Western value hierarchy, or pro Chinese value hierarchy), they might pressure to boycott, so they would avoid this choice. Or supply without advertisement. [6] Or the opposite: They might embrace that possibility to associate themselves with a value hierarchy. [7]
d)	The US-Administration does not have direct authority over the USOPC [7], but could still hinder the USOPC’s attendance through political means, like travel restrictions. Reasons for this might either be an ad hoc decision, more likey under Trump 2, or stem from an express strategy, more likely under Biden 1. As of now, there seems to be no express public strategy by the receding dominant power in the US-China Thucydides's Trap, like the Cold War was against the Soviet Union. With the power dynamics being continually at play, as noted in examples by @chiefthe, for both options I increase the initial 3,8% odds slightly to 4,8%, giving 5% as current (09/03/20) answer.
